posts.name: aniketh
posts.cooked:
Hello everyone,

We have been working on improving our drive code for this season, and we‚Äôve noticed that when the bot moves very fast, either in terms of translation or rotation, there is a strange movement in the opposing direction.

For example, if the robot was to rotate clockwise at the highest speed we can for a few seconds, then when we let go of the joystick, the robot will rotate counterclockwise very slowly for a couple seconds, as if it was trying to correct for something via PID or MotionMagic. We use YAGSL and PathPlanner for our code, and here is the codebase: GitHub - CougarProgramming623/reefscape at drivetrain

Thank you for any help, we cannot seem to find any reason why this problem is occuring.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Could you post a video so it‚Äôs easier to see what kind of error you‚Äôre getting?

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: Have you tried increasing your controller deadband

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: I doubt this would be the case as they said this error happened at high speeds.

Haven‚Äôt uploaded videos here before but I assume this works. It seems to output slowly in the opposite direction in this case, but in other cases it will drift in a seemingly random direction when we drive all over the place. Let us know what you think it might be. It just came to mind that if our drive motors have too high of an I value for their PID controller, they might output that slight amount in order to ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù for what might be an over-output. I will try to see if that fixes the problem‚Äìand thank you for your help.

posts.name: Evan McDonald
posts.cooked: Are you using a gyro by chance anywhere? My team noticed that after our climb, or fast jostling motions, our bot would have a slow turning drift. We could then turn our bot off and reconnect and be fine. Our programmers attributed this to our gyro needing to be reset after fast motions like that.
Yes, we do have a gyro (NavX), but what about the gyro would need to be reset after those fast actions?

posts.name: Evan McDonald
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm not a programmer, so I‚Äôd have to ask them, sorry.

I‚Äôm not sure if we fixed it either. I‚Äôll get back to this when I get the chance to ask them.

posts.name: Logan Bachman
posts.cooked:
You do not need to reset the gyro, you can add a button to reset it to 0 for the drivers but it is not necessary. From the video it looks like it is a weird center of gravity on your chassis which might be doing it.

Reading the original post more I see that you say it rotates the opposite direction after stopping and watching the end of the video it could be pid loop issue, possibly D is either too low or too high
I see. I‚Äôll try readjusting the PID on the drive motors and see how it works. Thank you very much.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: A drift of this magnitude is very normal. It could be caused by a number of things that aren‚Äôt that likely to inhibit your performance. If you really want to get to the bottom of this, you could try rezeroing your swerve modules, making sure they‚Äôre actually going to exactly the position you tell them to, or checking for friction in any of the modules. Even a slight issue with anything on your bot could cause an error like that. (I wouldn‚Äôt be too worried)
Hey, thanks for helping out with this. We got rid of our I value and heavily reduced the D value for the drive motors, and it seems like our issues are fixed.
